summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from April 2020 discussing a backlog in processing digital evidence (CART) for the Epstein case and another high-priority matter. The emails reveal coordination issues and resource constraints affecting the investigation's progress during office work reductions.

persons.name: Steve
persons.role: FBI personnel (possibly CART or case agent)
persons.context: Mentioned as potentially assigned to the Epstein case; the email asks about his assignment status regarding processing search warrants.

events.title: FBI discusses CART backlog for Epstein case evidence
events.description: Internal FBI emails reveal a significant backlog in the Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) processing digital evidence from searches related to the Epstein case and another high-priority matter, exacerbated by reduced office work during this period.

keyFacts: The FBI was experiencing a backlog in processing digital evidence (electronic downloads) from searches in the Epstein investigation as of April 2020.
The Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) was reportedly only in the office 1-2 days a week, contributing to delays in forensic evidence processing.
The Epstein case was described as a 'high priority matter with a mountain of forensic evidence to process' alongside another unnamed high-priority case.
FBI personnel discussed using a period of office work reduction to conduct evidence review (taint review, electronic search reviews) but were hampered by the CART backlog.
